awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoc Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Convergent evolution of biotic pollination in wind-pollinated angiosperm linages: functional and genomic exploration of a rare transition
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Research Using Biological Collections. The fellow, Elliot Gardner, is conducting research and receiving training that utilizes biological collections in innovative ways, and is being mentored by two sponsoring scientists at two host institutions: Andrew Hipp at The Morton Arboretum and Robert Raguso at Cornell University. The fellow's research project uses field studies, DNA sequencing of museum collections, and chemical analysis of floral scent to investigate convergent evolution of animal pollination of plants, specifically the oak, mulberry, and palm families. Transitions from wind to animal pollination are considered rare but likely represent an important pattern of flowering plant evolution. Although not closely related, these diverse plant families have all evolved similar dense spikes of tiny flowers that use scent to attract small insect pollinators, and these insects often use the flowers as brood sites. The fellow's research challenges some assumptions about the evolution of animal pollination, providing an important foundation for future studies on pollination transitions and, more generally, convergent evolution. The project is improving our understanding of the biology of diverse tropical trees - including important but underutilized crops - and promoting international cooperation with researchers in developing countries. The fellow is contributing to public education and outreach programs, as well as research opportunities for high-school and undergraduate students.

This project will produce a multidimensional picture of convergent transitions from wind to insect pollination in three divergent lineages. Data from field studies, herbarium specimens, and chemical (GC-MS) analysis of floral scent will support ancestral state reconstructions and phylogenetic comparative analyses to reveal patterns associated with transitions. Targeted sequencing of the entire terpene synthase gene family - involved in floral scent production - will reveal gene duplication and loss as well as molecular signatures of selection associated with pollination transitions. Using herbarium specimens will enable dense sampling within the target clades, highlighting the potential of museum collections for targeted next-generation sequencing. The project will generate a trait data base and genomic resources for hundreds of taxa, and clarify phylogenetic relationships in three important clades. Results will provide insight into a remarkable pattern of convergent evolution, and may shed light on the emergence of biotic pollination in ancient lineages such as cycads, whose fragrant cones resemble the convergent pattern described here. The fellow is teaching a portion of an advanced phylogenetics course, and engaging in outreach to the public and younger students through the host institution.

por.por_cntn:
This Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology provided essential training and career development for the Fellow. The project investigated transitions between wind and animal pollination in the mulberry, oak, and palm families, and advanced the taxonomy of the ecologically and economically important mulberry family.

Training and research collaboration: The Fellow conducted research in museum collections and botanic gardens in the US and abroad, developing robust collaborations within the US as well as between institutions in the US, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore. The Fellow received training in molecular and traditional systematics, field biology, and the analysis of plant volatile chemicals; he also taught an undergraduate course on biological classification. These activitieshave been essential in early-career trajectory of the Fellow. The collaborations are still active and continue to promote research in plant science and conservation.

Publications, lectures, and other products: To date, 12 peer-reviewed articles arising from the project have been published and deposited in the NSF Public Access Repository. One additional article is in review, and at least three more are planned. The Fellow delivered five lectures at international scientific meetings and gave three invited seminars and one workshop based on project results. Laboratory and computational work by the Fellow generated new genetic data for hundreds of species; the DNA sequences have been deposited in publicly-accessible databases for free use by future researchers. The project also led to the collection of hundreds of new specimens, which have been deposited as herbarium collections replicated in the US and Malaysia.

Research results: Project results provided a detailed look at transitions between wind and insect pollination in three lineages of plants, illustrating that while pollination mode is an important driver of evolution, the frequency and nature of shifts in pollination mode vary widely by lineage and appear to be depend on many factors, especially the pre-existing morphology of the plants.

Mulberry family: This project produced the most up-to-date systematic account of the tribe Moreae (true mulberries and their allies), supported by the lated molecular methods, resulting in the publication of a revision of the genera in that tribe. That strudy revealed that contrary to some older hypotheses, wind pollination was confined to a particular lineage; instead, it was widespread but lost multiple times in the evolutionary history of the mulberry family. One surprising finding was the relatively close alliance between Streblus and the lineage containing figs, shedding further light on the evolution of the unique structure of the fig. The project also advanced the taxonomy of the breadfruit and jackfrui genus (Artocarpus), leading to the publication of two large studies updating the classification of this important genus, which contains several emerging and underutilized crops.

Oak family: The project resulted in a well-resolved reconstruction of the evolutionary history of oaks and their tropical allies, suggesting a single transition to wind pollination in oaks, follows by expansion in the cooler, drier climates. 

Chamaedorea palms: Project data produced the most complete evolutionary reconstruction to date and a thorough analysis of floral scent in Chamaedorea and its close allies. Analyses indicate that pollination mode is extremely labile in these palms, with wind and insect pollination co-existing, sometimes within the same species.
